condition.description:
Acne is a common skin disease that causes pimples. Pimples form when hair follicles under your skin clog up. Most pimples form on the face, neck, back, chest, and shoulders. Anyone can get acne, but it is common in teenagers and young adults. It is not serious, but it can cause scars.

No one knows exactly what causes acne. Hormone changes, such as those during the teenage years and pregnancy, probably play a role. There are many myths about what causes acne. Chocolate and greasy foods are often blamed, but there is little evidence that foods have much effect on acne in most people. Another common myth is that dirty skin causes acne; however, blackheads and pimples are not caused by dirt. Stress doesn't cause acne, but stress can make it worse.

If you have acne

  • Clean your skin gently
  • Try not to touch your skin
  • Avoid the sun

Treatments for acne include medicines and creams.

NIH: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases
condition.name: Acne

carousel_items: Take by mouth twice a day.
Don't suck on or chew the capsule because it can hurt your throat.
Absorption differs greatly depending on whether it's taken with food and what type food (high fat food or meals increase its absorption into the body).
Women need to be on two separate types of birth control and start one month before taking Accutane.
Not a good choice if you have family history of depression, liver disease, diabetes, heart disease, eating disorder, bone loss, asthma or food/drug allergies.
Your doctor will prescribe a dose custom-made for you based on your body weight so don't change your dose on your own.
Avoid some prescription and OTC drugs that interact including: vitamin A, tetracycline, progestin-only birth-control, Dilantin (phenytoin), corticosteroids, and St. John's Wort.
Some formulations contain soybean oil so be careful if you have any food allergies.
Don't worry if you miss a dose, just wait and take your next dose. Don't double your dose.
You'll need to have a pregnancy test and other blood testing once a month to check cholesterol and liver enzymes.

clock.tip: Works faster when taken with a high-fat meal.

basics.benefits_moa: Accutane is a medicine for severe acne. Researchers don't know exactly how it works, but it seems to make oil glands smaller and produce less oil. It also keeps cells under the skin's surface from becoming tough.
basics.bottom_line: Accutane may be the last hope if you have severe, resistant, nodular acne. Talk to your doctor about the risk of birth defects, serious side effects, access restrictions and required patient contract to make sure it's right for you.
downsides: Has a lot of very serious side effects, so think about weighing risks and benefits, and talk to your doctor.
Accutane is restricted to specific doctors and pharmacies through the iPledge program.
Make sure you're not pregnant before starting Accutane. It can cause serious birth defects.
Can raise the risk of suicidal thoughts or behavior that can continue after you stop it.

risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Research studies with real people found Accutane can cause harmful effects on unborn babies. There's also a risk if men take it. Talk to your doctor about other treatments if you're thinking of getting pregnant or starting a family. If you take Accutane as part of the iPledge program you won't be able to donate blood for at least a month after finishing treatment because of the risk of giving your donated blood to another woman who may be pregnant. Women who can become pregnant must use 2 reliable forms of contraception for 1 month before therapy, during therapy, and for 1 month after therapy. You'll also need to have regular pregnancy tests while taking Accutane.

risks_warnings.title: Suicidal thoughts or behavior
risks_warnings.description: Accutane may increase the risk of suicidal thoughts or behavior. Watch for worsening depression or any unusual changes in mood or behavior, especially during the first few months of treatment or when the dose changes. Report anything concerning to a doctor immediately.
risk_factors: History of depression or other psychiatric condition

description_processed.orig: Accutane may increase the risk of suicidal thoughts or behavior. Watch for worsening depression or any unusual changes in mood or behavior, especially during the first few months of treatment or when the dose changes. Report anything concerning to a doctor immediately.

risks_warnings.title: Increased pressure in the brain
risks_warnings.description: Cases of increased pressure in the brain, called pseudotumor cerebri, were reported in people taking Accutane, and in some who also took the antibiotic tetracycline.  Watch for symptoms of nausea, vomiting, or pounding headache. if this happens, stop taking the medicine and have your doctor check for changes in your eyes (optic disc swelling), which may be a symptom.

risks_warnings.title: Serious skin reaction
risks_warnings.description: Accutane can cause skin reactions including erythema multiforme, red or purple blisters appearing on the skin. More serious reactions can be fatal. Tell your doctor if you notice any unusual or painful skin outbreak.

description_processed.orig: Accutane can cause skin reactions including erythema multiforme, red or purple blisters appearing on the skin. More serious reactions can be fatal. Tell your doctor if you notice any unusual or painful skin outbreak.

risks_warnings.title: Lipid abnormalities
risks_warnings.description: Accutane has negative effects on lipids causing very high triglycerides (fats) in the blood and lowering "good" cholesterol. You may need to check your cholesterol and triglycerides regularly while taking Accutane.

description_processed.orig: Accutane has negative effects on lipids causing very high triglycerides (fats) in the blood and lowering "good" cholesterol. You may need to check your cholesterol and triglycerides regularly while taking Accutane.

risks_warnings.title: Serious pancreatitis
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Accutane can cause serious and fatal inflammation of the pancreas (pancreatitis), with or without high levels of triglycerides (fats). If you're not able to control or improve  your triglycerides, then you may want to stop Accutane and try another medicine.
risk_factors: High triglyceride (fat) levels in the blood

risks_warnings.title: Liver injury
risks_warnings.description: Accutane can elevate your liver enzyme levels and cause injury. In some cases it's improved by lowering the dose or by continuing therapy. Your doctor will check these values and decide if you need to stop the medication.

risks_warnings.title: Hearing problems
risks_warnings.description: Accutane can cause loss of hearing that may last even after you stop the medicine. Let your doctor know if you notice ringing in your ears or any changes in your hearing.

description_processed.orig: Accutane can cause loss of hearing that may last even after you stop the medicine. Let your doctor know if you notice ringing in your ears or any changes in your hearing.

risks_warnings.title: Serious bowel problems
risks_warnings.description: There have been cases of Accutane causing inflammatory bowel disease. Stop taking and let your doctor know if you develop abdominal pain, diarrhea or rectal bleeding.

description_processed.orig: There have been cases of Accutane causing inflammatory bowel disease. Stop taking and let your doctor know if you develop abdominal pain, diarrhea or rectal bleeding.

risks_warnings.title: Bone and muscle effects
risks_warnings.description: Accutane can cause muscle weakness, joint and bone pain, back pain, and sudden onset of osteoporosis or bone fractures. This is especially the case in teenagers who play sports with repeat injury. There are also cases of early growth plate closure and loss of bone density that did not return to normal (pre-Accutane) in teenagers.
risk_factors: History of childhood osteoporosis or bone conditions

risks_warnings.title: Eye problems
risks_warnings.description: Accutane can worsen vision, especially at night, cloud or scar the cornea, dry the eyes and make it more difficult to wear contact lenses. Be careful driving, especially at night, until you know how this medicine affects you.

carousel_items: Combination medicine you apply to your skin to treat acne.
Apply a thin film to clean and dry affected skin twice a day- in the morning and evening.
Store in the refrigerator, but don't freeze.
The pharmacist mixes the medicine when you pick it up at the drugstore. You'll need to use it within three months of this date or dispose of it properly.
Let your doctor know if you notice abdominal discomfort, pain or diarrhea after starting this medicine.
Using a moisturizer that doesn't block your pores (non-comedogenic) may help lessen common side effects of skin dryness and peeling.
Taking good care of your skin is an important part of treating acne. Lightly wash with warm water and non-soap-based or gentle cleanser.

basics.benefits_moa: Benzamycin is a combination topical medicine. Erythromycin (an antibiotic) kills bacteria that cause acne. Benzoyl peroxide works to fight the bacteria and shed acne-affected skin.
basics.bottom_line: Benzamycin is a topical combination acne treatment that may work better for people who didn't see an improvement when taking either medicine alone or simply don't want to take pill medication. You need to be careful because it can bleach your hair, clothing and other fabrics. It also needs to be stored in the refrigerator and is only good for three months..
downsides: There's a risk of irritation with anything you apply to your skin and this is no different. Benzamycin, contains a topical antibiotic and can cause redness, peeling, abnormal dryness or stinging, tightening, or burning sensations.
It's rare, that a serious allergic reaction would occur, but it's a good idea to test a small area of skin before using on any larger or sensitive areas
Can cause severe inflammation of the large intestine (pseudomembranous colitis).
Not the best choice if you're pregnant. Benzamycin is categorized as pregnancy Category C (weight risks vs benefits) because of the benzoyl peroxide part.
Can cause bleaching of hair and clothing.
You'll need to stay out of the sun or apply a sunscreen if you go outdoors.

upsides: Benzamycin works better to reduce bacteria in oil glands and improve overall signs and symptoms of acne than either medicine alone.
Reduces bacteria on the skin, which "calms" the skin down (lowers the inflammatory response) in acne.
Combining an antibiotic with benzoyl peroxide lowers the chances of Benzamycin not working as well over time.
Although Benzamycin can irritate the skin, a true skin allergy is rare.
Can be used in combination with acne pill medicine if your doctor thinks you need it.

risks_warnings.title: Allergic reaction
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Benzamycin can cause serious allergic reactions and life-threatening organ failure. Report any skin rash, fever, swelling, or trouble breathing to a doctor immediately. It may occur immediately longer, after continued use.

description_processed.orig: Rarely, Benzamycin can cause serious allergic reactions and life-threatening organ failure. Report any skin rash, fever, swelling, or trouble breathing to a doctor immediately. It may occur immediately longer, after continued use.

risks_warnings.title: Development of more serious infections
risks_warnings.description: Although the amount of Benzamycin that's absorbed in the body is very low when it's applied to the skin, using it for a long period of time can cause a fungal infection or more serious bacterial infection including c-difficile diarrhea and severe colitis.  It can happen more than 2 months after stopping treatment. If you develop significant diarrhea while taking Benzamycin or after stopping it, let you doctor know right away.

carousel_items: Acne can take several weeks to show up in the skin so it's best to use for 2-3 months before you decide it doesn't work.
Studies showed it didn't matter what strength people used, they all took about the same time to work.
Higher strengths greater than 2.5% may not work any better but might cause more side effects.
Using a moisturizer that doesn't block your pores (non-comedogenic) may help lessen common side effects of skin dryness and peeling.
Taking good care of your skin is an important part of treating acne. Lightly wash with warm water and non-soap-based or gentle cleanser.

basics.benefits_moa: Benzoyl peroxide is a topical acne medicine. It seems to fight the bacteria responsible for producing acne in oil (sebaceous) glands, and dries out acne-affected areas. Also, it speeds up growth of damaged skin from serious breakdown, injury, or disease.
basics.bottom_line: Benzoyl peroxide is a very popular topical acne treatment you can get over-the-counter or by prescription that may be better for people who don't want to take pill medication. Just be careful because it can bleach your hair, clothing and other fabrics.
downsides: Higher strengths (concentrations) can cause skin irritation and may appear as redness, peeling, abnormal dryness or stinging, tightening, or burning sensations.
It's rare, that a serious allergic reaction would occur, but it's a good idea to test a small area of skin before using on any larger or sensitive areas.

Not the best choice if you're pregnant. Benzoyl peroxide is categorized as pregnancy Category C (weigh risks vs benefits) as compared to similar topical medicines that are in Category B (likely safe).
Can cause bleaching of hair and clothing.
May not work as well when used by itself over long period of time.
You'll need to stay out of the sun or apply a sunscreen if you have to be outdoors.

basics.benefits_moa: Clindamycin is an antibiotic and acne medicine. It kills bacteria by preventing them from reproducing and repairing themselves.
basics.bottom_line: Clindamycin is good for treating many bacterial infections and is available as a generic. If you're taking the vaginal form, you have to avoid sex and tampons for the period your doctor tells you to. The topical form can cause skin sensitivity and irritation.
downsides: Have to take the oral forms with a full glass of liquid or with food since it can cause irritation in your stomach and esophagus.

If you're allergic to aspirin, your doctor may have to prescribe an alternate.
If you have to take live vaccines, talk to your doctor when to take them since Clindamycin can make it less effective.

risks_warnings.title: Diarrhea
risks_warnings.description: As with all antibiotics, Clindamycin can cause diarrhea. If this happens while you're taking the medication, taking probiotics in the form of yogurt, supplements or drinks a few hours after you take the medication may help. If you develop an unusual diarrhea with loose or bloody stools weeks after you finish the medication, talk to your doctor as this can be a rare but serious side effect.

carousel_items: Very commonly used topical antibiotic to treat acne.
The only topical erythromycin in a gel formula.
Apply a thin film to clean and dry affected skin once or twice a day.
It may take 6-8 weeks before you see improvement in your acne.
Avoid getting into your eyes, nose or mouth.

Taking good care of your skin is an important part of treating acne. Lightly wash with warm water and non-soap-based or gentle cleanser.

basics.benefits_moa: Erythromycin is a topical antibiotic. It fights bacteria that cause acne in oil (sebaceous) glands, and contains alcohol which dries out acne-affected areas.
basics.bottom_line: Erythromycin is a very common acne treatment you apply to the skin that may work better when combined with other topical medicines.
downsides: There's a risk of irritation with anything you apply to your skin and this is no different. erythromycin, like other topical antibiotics, can cause skin irritation and may appear as redness, peeling, abnormal dryness or stinging, tightening, or burning sensations.
It's rare, that a serious allergic reaction would occur, but it's a good idea to test a small area of skin before using on any larger or sensitive areas
Studies show it works better when combined with other topical medicines to fight acne and reduce the risk of it losing its effectiveness over time.
Can cause severe inflammation of the large intestine (pseudomembranous colitis)
Stop using if you don't notice any improvement in your acne after 6-8 weeks. The most time you can use it is three months.

risks_warnings.title: Development of more serious infections

It can happen more than 2 months after stopping treatment. If you develop significant diarrhea while taking Erythromycin or after stopping it, let you doctor know right away.

basics.benefits_moa: Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that prevents and treats a variety of infections. It works by preventing bacteria from growing and multiplying.

downsides: Interacts with a lot of drugs, so don't take it with colchicine, statin drugs, verapamil, amlodipine, or diltiazem.
Diarrhea and other stomach problems are common side effects.
Can cause liver problems, so people with previous liver problems need to be closely monitored while on Erythromycin.

basics.benefits_moa: Tetracycline is an antibiotic. It prevents bacteria from growing, reproducing, and repairing themselves. It also changes your immune system response (immunomodulating effect), which helps treat skin conditions.
basics.bottom_line: Tetracycline treats many different types of infections and is cheap, but dosing and drug interactions may be somewhat of a hassle.
downsides: For most infections you'll need to take it 4 times a day (or every 6 hours).

Interacts with birth control and makes it less effective. Use a backup form of birth control if you don't want to get pregnant.
Not a good choice for children ages 8 and under. Tetracycline can cause permanent staining of teeth in babies and young children.

risks_warnings.title: Changes in teeth
risks_warnings.description: Tetracycline and similar medicines can affect the growth and development of teeth in the fetus, infant and in children younger than 8 years old. Avoid using if you're pregnant, breast-feeding, or in children less than 8 years of age and ask your doctor about other effective medicine choices.

risks_warnings.title: Reduced effectiveness of birth control pills
risks_warnings.description: If you're taking Tetracycline and also on birth control pills, the birth control might not work. You'll need to use a barrier form of birth control (condoms, diaphragms, etc.) while taking Tetracycline if you don't want to get pregnant.

description_processed.orig: If you're taking Tetracycline and also on birth control pills, the birth control might not work. You'll need to use a barrier form of birth control (condoms, diaphragms, etc.) while taking Tetracycline if you don't want to get pregnant.

risks_warnings.title: Decreased kidney function and kidney injury
risks_warnings.description: Tetracycline can lower your kidney function causing buildup of substances that should be removed from the body. There's a higher risk if you have current problems with your kidneys. It's also important that you don't take Tetracycline past the expiration date on your prescription label. This was more of a problem with older forms of the medicine, which could change and damage your kidneys.
risk_factors: Taking Tetracycline past the expiration date

risks_warnings.title: Sunburn
risks_warnings.description: If you're taking Tetracycline and have to be outside in the sun for any amount of time, make sure you wear sunblock on exposed parts of your body or protective clothing. Your skin can be more sensitive to the sun and you're at a higher risk for sunburn.

risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: You should avoid taking Tetracycline if you think you may get pregnant. Tetracycline can affect tooth and bone formation in the developing fetus and infant. The risk is greater the longer you take it, but can happen even with repeated short treatments. If you're considering having a baby, talk to your doctor first about safer medicine choices to treat your condition.

risks_warnings.title: Increased pressure in the brain
risks_warnings.description: Tetracycline may cause increased pressure in the brain, called pseudotumor cerebri in infants and adults. There's more risk if you also take the drug Accutane. If you notice symptoms of nausea, vomiting, or pounding headache stop taking it and your symptoms should improve. Your doctor can check for changes in your eyes (optic disc swelling) before having you continue treatment.
risk_factors: Taking with Tetracycline with other medicines that can cause this effect (e.g. Accutane)

risks_warnings.title: Liver injury
risks_warnings.description: Liver injury can happen rarely with Tetracycline. There's a higher risk if you have kidney disease. Your doctor should check your liver function before starting you on Tetracycline.

risks_warnings.title: Development of more serious infections
risks_warnings.description: Using Tetracycline for a long period of time can cause a fungal infection or more serious bacterial infection including c-difficile diarrhea and severe colitis.  It can happen more than 2 months after stopping treatment. If you develop significant diarrhea while taking Tetracycline or after stopping it, let you doctor know right away.

basics.benefits_moa: Accutane is a medicine for severe acne. Researchers don't know exactly how it works, but it seems to make oil glands smaller and produce less oil. It also keeps cells under the skin's surface from becoming tough.
basics.bottom_line: Accutane may be the last hope if you have severe, resistant, nodular acne. Talk to your doctor about the risk of birth defects, serious side effects, access restrictions and required patient contract to make sure it's right for you.
downsides: Has a lot of very serious side effects, so think about weighing risks and benefits, and talk to your doctor.
Accutane is restricted to specific doctors and pharmacies through the iPledge program.

risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Research studies with real people found Accutane can cause harmful effects on unborn babies. There's also a risk if men take it. Talk to your doctor about other treatments if you're thinking of getting pregnant or starting a family. If you take Accutane as part of the iPledge program you won't be able to donate blood for at least a month after finishing treatment because of the risk of giving your donated blood to another woman who may be pregnant. Women who can become pregnant must use 2 reliable forms of contraception for 1 month before therapy, during therapy, and for 1 month after therapy. You'll also need to have regular pregnancy tests while taking Accutane.

risks_warnings.title: Suicidal thoughts or behavior

risks_warnings.title: Serious skin reaction
risks_warnings.description: Accutane can cause skin reactions including erythema multiforme, red or purple blisters appearing on the skin. More serious reactions can be fatal. Tell your doctor if you notice any unusual or painful skin outbreak.

risks_warnings.title: Lipid abnormalities
risks_warnings.description: Accutane has negative effects on lipids causing very high triglycerides (fats) in the blood and lowering "good" cholesterol. You may need to check your cholesterol and triglycerides regularly while taking Accutane.

risks_warnings.title: Serious pancreatitis
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Accutane can cause serious and fatal inflammation of the pancreas (pancreatitis), with or without high levels of triglycerides (fats). If you're not able to control or improve  your triglycerides, then you may want to stop Accutane and try another medicine.

risks_warnings.title: Liver injury
risks_warnings.description: Accutane can elevate your liver enzyme levels and cause injury. In some cases it's improved by lowering the dose or by continuing therapy. Your doctor will check these values and decide if you need to stop the medication.

risks_warnings.title: Serious bowel problems

risks_warnings.title: Bone and muscle effects
risks_warnings.description: Accutane can cause muscle weakness, joint and bone pain, back pain, and sudden onset of osteoporosis or bone fractures. This is especially the case in teenagers who play sports with repeat injury. There are also cases of early growth plate closure and loss of bone density that did not return to normal (pre-Accutane) in teenagers.

basics.benefits_moa: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that blocks aldosterone (a hormone) and helps the kidney get rid of excess fluids in your body.

downsides: Not very good at getting rid of excess fluids on its own. Should be used with another drug to help get rid of excess fluids.
